properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant high-elevation snowfall and coastal rainfall will continue. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Much less along the coast. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: continuing until Sunday morning. Remarks: Accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations of the Long Range Mountains. Anyone planning travel across higher parts of the Trans Canada Highway, Viking Trail or Roddickton Highway should expect winter driving conditions. Users of backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. Conditions may deteriorate suddenly over short distances. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:29:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:30:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1168351692.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries at times heavy are expected. Snow squalls are likely as a cold northerly flow develops over the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Total snowfall: locally up to 20 cm by Saturday afternoon. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia and western Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tonight until Saturday evening. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy will persist tonight and Saturday. Snow squalls with locally poor visibility are likely as well. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T10:59:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T21:44:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1967241250.2019
Area: Cumberland County North and Cobequid Pass, Colchester County North
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow will continue. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm except near 30 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River. Time span: continuing until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:51:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:52:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2104977264.2019
Area: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring significant snowfall to the region beginning Sunday and continuing through Sunday night before tapering off Monday morning. The bulk of the precipitation is expected to fall throughout the day on Sunday. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low however there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T13:15:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T21:16:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2993975218.2019

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northerly winds expected tonight through Saturday night. Maximum gusts: 100 to 110 km/h. Location: Hawke's Bay to Port Aux Basques. Time span: beginning early this evening and continuing until roughly midnight on Saturday night. Remarks: Maximum gusts are expected mainly along coastal areas exposed to the north or northwest. Winds should begin to diminish after midnight on Saturday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:31:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:32:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4190595147.2019
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: 3 to 7 metres. Locations: North facing shorelines of The Gulf of St. Lawrence, Northumberland Strait and Cabot Strait. Time span: Tonight, Saturday, then subsiding on Sunday. Remarks: The highest waves will be at north facing shorelines of the Magdalen Islands, Prince Edward Island and Cape Breton where waves of 5 to 7 metres and water levels of near a metre above normal are expected. Over north facing shorelines of New Brunswick and mainland Nova Scotia, wave heights are expected to be in the 3 to 4 metre range with a water level of 50 cm to 1 metre above normal. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:25:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T19:26:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2780244478.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected late Saturday night into Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring a messy mix of weather to the area beginning late Saturday night or early Sunday morning. Some areas could see several hours of freezing rain or ice pellets before transitioning to rain or light snow late Sunday morning or Sunday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northerly winds expected overnight tonight and again Saturday night. Maximum gusts: near 100 km/h. Location: The Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: From midnight until early morning of both tonight and Saturday night. Remarks: Maximum gusts are expected mainly along coastal areas exposed to the north or northwest. Winds during the day on Saturday will remain strong, with gusts likely near 80 km/h. Winds will begin to diminish on Sunday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix expected Sunday. A strengthening low pressure system is expected to bring a messy mix of weather to the area beginning early Sunday morning. Some areas could see several hours of freezing rain or ice pellets before transitioning to snow Sunday afternoon. Light snow is then expected to continue through Sunday night before tapering off Monday morning. There remains some uncertainty as to the track of the low however there is the potential that some areas could see total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T13:21:01-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief blizzard conditions are possible early this afternoon for Ulukhaktok. However, the most likely area for these conditions to occur is now forecast to be south of the community over the Amundsen Gulf. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:19:02-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixture of significant wintry precipitation will continue. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except 20 to 30 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast and over lower elevation areas of the Humber Valley. Locations: Higher elevation areas of route 430 and the Baie Verte Peninsula. Time span: continuing until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow and rain will continue tonight and Saturday. Snowfall accumulations will be highly variable, with the highest totals occurring inland and over higher elevations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T11:26:24-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions are favourable for the development of snow squalls through Saturday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T12:41:53-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Highlands and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tonight through to Saturday evening. Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will continue to give flurries and snow squalls tonight and accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T13:43:02-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle has been occurring at Brandon since the overnight hours, and is likely also occurring throughout much of southwestern Manitoba. Conditions will continue to be favourable for freezing drizzle through the night tonight and early Saturday morning, after which time drier air should end most of the precipitation. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snow tonight then gradually tapering off Saturday in Pangnirtung. Another 5 cm will fall on Saturday before the snow tapers off later in the day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Areas of freezing drizzle are expected or occurring. Freezing drizzle has been occurring from time to time since last night over portions of southeastern Saskatchewan as moist easterly winds and temperatures just below the freezing mark continue. Freezing drizzle will likely become more widespread over the southeast this evening. The freezing drizzle should end Saturday morning as the precipitation gradually changes to light snow and tapers off. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will continue to give flurries and snow squalls tonight and accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T13:43:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T21:44:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1039209758.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong, potentially damaging winds will gust to 90 kilometres per hour beginning overnight tonight and continuing into Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 110 km/h. Locations: Rigolet to Black Tickle. Time span: tonight until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will transition to snow at times heavy tonight and persist into Sunday. Strong northerly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and ease Sunday afternoon. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Very strong southwest winds tonight in Cape Dorset. Strong west to southwest winds continue at Cape Dorset late this afternoon. The strongest winds, southwest as high as 70 gusting 100 km/h are expected tonight. An approaching low pressure trough will bring lighter winds late overnight and for Saturday. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy fog is lingering in southern Alberta late this afternoon. As the sun sets this evening, a more widespread area of fog is forecast to redevelop. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
